key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the most cost-effective method for reducing unwanted catch in commercial fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several methods have been demonstrated to reduce unwanted catch in commercial fisheries.
[Statement 2]: Using larger mesh sizes showed the strongest evidence for effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 3]: Fifteen of twenty studies found that larger mesh nets reduced catches of unwanted fish compared to standard or smaller mesh sizes.
[Statement 4]: Using larger mesh sizes improved size-selectivity for fish species in 19 of 21 studies.
[Statement 5]: Three of four studies found that modifications to gillnet configurations reduced unwanted catch of various fish species.
[Statement 6]: For trap fisheries, increasing mesh size appeared to reduce unwanted undersized mud crab catches in controlled studies.
[Statement 7]: For trap fisheries, fitting escape frames appeared to reduce unwanted undersized mud crab catches in controlled studies.
[Statement 8]: More technologically advanced approaches to reducing unwanted catch showed mixed but promising results.
[Statement 9]: Technology to communicate near real-time catch information to fishers reduced unwanted catch or discards in two of three cases.
[Statement 10]: Setting catch limits or quotas for non-target species reduced unwanted catch in two of three cases.
[Statement 11]: Setting catch limits or quotas for non-target species reduced unwanted halibut in one study.
[Statement 12]: Combined gear modifications also demonstrated effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 13]: Trawl nets with escape grids and square mesh codends caught fewer unwanted fish species compared to diamond mesh codends with no grid.
